newsitem.title: USA: Glickman sees big battle over gene-modified crops.
newsitem.headline: Glickman sees big battle over gene-modified crops.

text.p: U.S. Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman warned on Tuesday that the U.S. could find itself in a major dispute with the European Union and other trading partners over the safety of genetically-modified crops.
"This is really shaping up to be the battle royale of 21st century world agriculture," Glickman said in a speech to the Commodity Club, a group of agricultural industry lobbyists.
A growing portion of U.S. corn, soybean and other crops comes from seed varieties that have been genetically-modified to produce higher yields.
In many cases, the genetically-modified crops require less water and other agricultural inputs than traditional crops.

However, many consumers, especially in Europe, have strong concerns about the safety of genetically-modified crops and would like to see them kept separate from traditional crops throughout the marketing chain. That would make it much easier for food processors to label whether their products contain genetically-modified ingredients or not.

The U.S. grain industry is strongly opposed to segregation because of the huge costs involved. They also argue the action is unnecessary because the crops are not a threat to human health, a view upheld by the U.S. government.

In his speech, Glickman repeated that the U.S. "will not tolerate" any requirement to segragate genetically-modified crops and said the U.S. would use its options under the World Trade Organization to prevent that from happening.
But hectoring the European Union on the unfair trade aspects of segregation is "a losing argument," Glickman said.
The U.S. must convince opponents that genetically-modified crops and other biotechnology innovations are needed to feed "a growing world in a sustainable way," he said.
